Wednesday 2nd November 2011
Curriculum Information
Dear Parents,
As announced to you earlier in the school year, the Secondary Department will no longer be sending home a weekly blurb containing curriculum information. This blurb will now be replaced with a far more detailed curriculum letter. Attached to this letter is the curriculum information for all subjects for the remainder of this Autumn Term. In January a new curriculum letter will go home containing information for the Spring Term and a final letter will go home in April with details for the Summer Term.
If you have any questions pertaining to the information contained in this curriculum letter, please speak to the individual teachers at our parent teacher conferences over the next two weeks.
Kind regards
Mrs. Hamilton
Key Stage Three Phase Leader
Autumn Term 2 – Curriculum Map (Year 8)
English
An Introduction to Dickens (cont.) & Travel Writing & ‘Journeys’
Grammar and punctuation • Comment on the use of a wide range of punctuation to convey shades of meaning. • Use accurate punctuation including commas in various situations, including parenthetical commas, colons, semi-colons, dashes and brackets. • Begin to use formal and informal language for specific purposes. • Demonstrate controlled use of a variety of simple and complex sentences to achieve purpose and contribute to overall effect. • Confidently use a range of sentence features to clarify or emphasise meaning, e.g. fronted adverbials, complex nouns or prepositional phrases.
Phonics, spelling and vocabulary • Spell most words correctly, including some complex polysyllabic words and unfamiliar words. • Learn the spelling of difficult and commonly misspelt words and develop strategies for correcting spelling. • Learn an increasingly wide range of vocabulary appropriate to their needs.
Non-fiction • Use a range of reading strategies to find relevant information and main points in texts, distinguishing between fact and opinion where appropriate. • Make relevant notes when researching different sources, comparing and contrasting information. • Explain how specific choices and combinations of form, layout and presentation create particular effects. • Demonstrate understanding of the effects created by features of diaries, magazines and newspaper reports. • Demonstrate understanding of the main features, including the structure, of each genre and text type studied.

French
Unit 5 (end of) : Ma famille (Family and other people) · Le matin, chez moi (Morning routines; reflexive verbs) : we will learn how to use reflexive verbs and how to build a sentence in the negative form.
Unit 6 : On mange! (Food and meals) · On va au café? (Places to eat; food) : we will learn French prepositions (au, à la = at, in , to) while learning new vocabulary. · S’il-vous-plaît! (Ordering food; prices) : we will revise numbers, prepositions and focus on dialogues. · Ma recette préférée (Recipes : ingredients and quantities) : we will learn numbers above 100 and talk about quantities while learning new vocabulary. · Mange bien! (Healthy eating) : We will learn how to describe one’s diet using negatives and we will learn the future tense. · French cuisine : we will conclude this unit by learning more about the culture of food in France and around the world and we will focus on the career of a famous French chef.

Drama
· Review of First Half Term: characterization, hot seating, conflict, high and low status · Gesture, voice, posture, proximity, facial expression, use of levels · Areas, features and types of stage; stage directions and blocking; director’s shorthand; drawing stage sets · Key rules of stage movement · Analysis of blocking: Twelve Angry Men · Script analysis and performance of extract: Twelve Angry Men · Narrative structure: The Wizard of Oz · Writing, directing and performing group pieces based upon stimulus photographs · Dramatisation of contemporary themes and historical events · Communication and presentation skills · Analysis of advertising · Declamation of poetry · Researching a historical period from the points of view of costume, make up, setting, stage properties and music
PE
Rugby/ Fitness Testing Pupils will continue to develop their understanding of the Principles of Play by taking part in Rugby. Due to the nature of the activity, pupils will learn an adapted Rugby League style of play. Pupils will firstly develop fundamental handling skills which will be transferred into a full game situation. Secondly, pupils will link their handling skills with the ability to outwit their opponents in a rugby setting. Practices will be set up to allow pupils to implement the handling skills they have learnt and refined. Following this, pupils will develop other key skills such as kicking and running with the ball which will allow them to be an effective performer in the sport of rugby. As well as skills, pupils will be given ample opportunity to develop strategic and tactical thinking relating to the principles of play. These thinking skills will allow the pupils to transfer them across all invasion games. Towards the end of this term, pupils will take part in a variety of fitness tests. This will allow them to identify their strengths and weaknesses and suggest ways in which they can improve. All tests will be retaken in term two and three. Key Skills: -Handling – Lateral pass, miss pass, switch pass, loop pass, scrum half pass from ground, scrum half dive pass -Committing a defender – fixing defender, attacking space, decision making, P.A.S.S. (positioning, angles, speed, space) -Running with the ball – Side step, change of pace, the swerve. -Kicking – The punt, the grubber kick, the drop kick -Team work – Running from depth, creating passing angles, developing continuity and support -Tactics and Strategies – Principles of play in attack and defence
